In my upcoming book HYSTERICAL I also examine the trope of 'angry black woman' seen repeatedly in media targeted even at Serena Williams & Michelle Obama, silencing them, denigrating their achievements. These stereotypes feed into violence against Black girls & dehumanise them.

I wrote about 'adultification' and hyper-sexualisation of Black girls in my book SWAY. They are also seen as 'angry' & 'aggressive'. Once these stereotypes become ingrained within a workplace culture such as police, they are rarely questioned, leading to more racial profiling. https://t.co/7g1NrJtq7R

@BBCWomansHour @sociologyblog I do, and my children do too. It is surprising/shocking that this still continues where children automatically take their father’s name. It is deeply patriarchal. I also find it surprising when people send me letters/cards in my husband’s name when I clearly use my maiden name.

@porridgebrain Yes! And goes on to say: “What woman's terms of oppression have become precious and necessary to her as a ticket into the fold of the righteous, away from the cold winds of self-scrutiny?” I think about it quite a lot.

As Audre Lorde said:“What woman here is so enamoured of her own oppression that she cannot see her heel print upon another woman's face?" And, we all have to reflect on how oppression is not a monolith but works along a spectrum of privilege and bias.

I completely & resolutely stand for women's rights, yes. But any struggle for equality can only be intersectional. If your feminism does not include trans women & other marginalised groups then it's not feminism. If you do not agree & want to unfollow me that's absolutely fine.

@mrianleslie Well Ian I don’t mind the discussion but it isn’t exactly a good eve when what your tweets did was to attract and send a whole lot of transphobic abuse my way that has now filled up my DMs.

You've done talks on gender equality & anti-racism all day & then your 5-yr old asks questions that makes your brain fizz: 
What is freedom?
Would I have been a slave? But my skin is also dark colour?
What does equality look like?
But why don't we have equality already?

When I was pitching my hybrid memoir, two white women lit agents said ‘I don’t find your voice relatable’. And here is how experiences of people with marginalised identities are often not given a platform. https://t.co/awKfDVqueP
@yumcoconutmilk He is so shit

@mrianleslie I don’t think of as a ‘mantra’. I think of it as a fact. As a woman, I find it very easy to think of it as a fact. Why after centuries of struggling to find our way outside the boxes that have trapped women, are some people still keen to put rigid boundaries around this term?

@mrianleslie Too tired to argue but as I said trans women are women & I believe that it is very helpful. It depends on what you think a woman is and how expansive that label is. I am confident that most women have no issues with this being a broader category and being inclusive.
@mrianleslie Erm

I am too tired to engage with all the discourse here but just to say trans women are women and acknowledging this does not take anyone’s rights away and definitely does not silence any women. That is all.

Linking womanhood to motherhood or to our wombs is conforming to patriarchal norms. I would have thought that anyone and everyone would wish to disrupt these expectations. How can we discuss womanhood and motherhood without an intersectional lens?

The mumsnet discourse around motherhood and trans rights is so toxic. Being a mother, and a cis woman, I am aware of how our bodies and our identities give us privileges while also cause oppression. This should make us more inclusive, not less.

Things have of course changed so much through the years, and her world, and the world in general opened up. But then it was about her making sure her children were respectful of everyone who was different to us, and learnt to value everyone's culture and traditions.

She always made paneer. Paneer used to be expensive too and that was a dish for special occasions and festivals for us. She would make it with a really lush cashew and tomato gravy. I have never been able to recreate it.

make a steamed cake. I remember it being not that great but we were all so excited. So excited to have a homemade 'cake'. I don't think she found the proper ingredients in our small corner shop, but she improvised. It was so much fun to see what she would come up with.

Then she tried to bake a Christmas cake for us, because she read in a magazine that it is what people ate on Christmas. But we didn't have an oven, and my mother didn't know anyone who baked. I remember her trying to find recipes in some old magazines that she had and try and

in a pot that we would bring inside every year and decorate it with some tinsel. And no matter how tight finances were, she would always have a small present for us. Mostly it was just a bar of chocolate which was a real luxury for us to have, one whole bar to ourselves!

own customs for us. She tried to get a Christmas tree but the idea was very novel in our small town, and shops weren't selling fake ones, so she sent my father to a lot of plant places to try and buy one. He managed to find a small plant, a very tiny real Christmas tree

wanted us to mark all festivals no matter what religious association. It isn't something families like us did so she was always seen as odd. There wasn't any internet for her to learn things from & she didn't know anyone who was Christian or celebrated Christmas. So she made up

Christmas when growing up. What are your childhood memories? I went to a Catholic school in India where we had huge Christmas celebrations, santa, nativity play (I once played one of the 3 kings!), christmas carols, the whole shebang. But this was just a school thing. My mother

So while the UK closes the borders for some, while the media plays up the dangers of immigration, the government is letting in rich people who are bringing in organised crime, and opening up the doors to those who can pay with little or no checks made on their wealth 10/

'The UK was going to ban these risky and unethical schemes but just nine months later they’ve sold the highest number since 2014, with very few applicants being rejected,” said an anti-corruption campaigner at Global Witness. Many of these are high-risk individuals. 9/

And despite the money laundering and rise in crime, the 'golden tickets', the visa afforded to the super rich in return of a min £2 million investment for a permanent residency has risen. The Home Office granted 255 people tier-1 investor visas in the first half of 2019. 8/

non-EEA partner to the UK must meet a minimum income requirement of £18,600 per year before tax. Close to 40% of British citizens working as employees in 2015 earned less than the income threshold. People are less likely meet the threshold if they are young or female. 7/

I am not sure why I am telling this story except to reflect on how this system only benefits those who already have all the resources, not those who do not. The visa process is difficult and expensive and draining and not transparent. Since July 2012 people applying to bring a 6/

This happened 4 times, 4 times we hoped and we tried, and I could not bring her over with me. Each time I had to justify, explain, viewed with suspicion. It was exhausting, mentally, physically and financially when it was all in limited supply. It affected so much of our life. 5/

I was not officially divorced, I did not have sole custody then, her biological father did not give us a letter to say that he agreed. My tiny daughter was interviewed in a booth, asked questions such as if she loved her father (horrible). And I was grilled about my intentions 4/

In a small room packed with people. No food allowed. I had all the documents, was doing a PhD on a scholarship & working part-time. BUT I did not have thousands of £s in my bank account. I did not own a house, I could not even rent a v large house that they considered suitable 3/

Each time, I had to book an appointment (not easy), and travel to the British High Commission for the appt in India (so I had to be there in India for it). Each time I had to fill many forms, pay for the visa (v v expensive) and then wait for the appt. for many hours. 2/

Recently a photo of the young Iraqi woman who was coming to the UK to join her fiance was being circulated. Why didn't she just get a visa, I saw people wondering and discussing. A story: My daughter's UK visa application was rejected 4 TIMES. She was only 4-5 yrs old 1/

1. We need more disaggregated data globally

3. We need rigorous policies & consequences for those who inflict violence
4. We need women’s testimonies to be taken seriously 7/

Trans women are women too. 2021 has already seen at least 48 transgender or gender non-conforming people killed violently, but much of this goes unreported and so this data is missing. Most were Black or Latina women. I don’t have any data for this in the UK. 6/

One hundred thirty-seven women are killed by a member of their family every day. It is estimated that of the 87,000 women who were intentionally killed in 2017 globally, more than half (50,000) were killed by intimate partners or family members. 5/
Calls to helplines have increased five-fold in some countries as rates of reported intimate partner violence increase because of the COVID-19 pandemic.4/

In 2018, an estimated one in seven women had experienced physical and/or sexual violence from an intimate partner or husband in the past 12 months (13 per cent of women aged 15 to 49). These numbers do not reflect the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic 3/
non-partner sexual violence, or both at least once in their life (30 per cent of women aged 15 and older). This figure does not include sexual harassment. 2/
